reviewText: This is a great movie that I had seen a few times on cable (DISNEY Channel)and I was glad to be able to get a copy of it online.  It is a great story about a proto-type weapon cyborg suit that is sent to earth by it's creators to escape destruction on it's own planet which is under attack.  A 12 year old boy, who is having problems of his own - lack of courage, etc. - finds the suit which he calls "Cy" and figures that his life can't possibly get any worse.  So he enters the suit as the biotic host and becomes one with Cy.  That's where the action begins.  He finds out that, since Cy is a prototype, they must engage and battle a hostile warrior, and what a battle they encounter!  The movie has a great story line and is full of comedy.  I highly recommend this movie to anyone looking for an entertaining 90 minutes to break from reality and get away from it all.  Kids of any age will really enjoy it too.  I would categorize it as soft science fiction, but it is really more of a drama comedy.

reviewText: Star Kid is a lighter film in the repertoire of Joseph Mazzello, and is the first movie where His name heads the cast.  He carries this movie almost solely by himself.  This is a fun FAMILY sort of film of the lighter sort and makes for a good time watch.But, there is more to this movie.  The vast number of close-ups of Joseph's face (when he is inside the alien-built cyber-suit) is a STUDY in good acting-concentration.  I never knew that Joe's face was that expressive ( and while we are on this topic, did ANYONE catch Joe "pulling a Bugs Bunny" with his eye brows, in an early scene of Simon Birch?).  Anyway, my point is that Joseph has a RARE and magical face that is wonderfully expressive.  Star Kid is solid, and a fun flick to watch over popcorn or hot coco.  For those who are BIG Joseph Mazzello fans, this film is "Sine Qua Non"--indespensable--for your collection.You see more of him than anyone else and he carries this film from A-to-Z.Best of all, it is Joe's first significant work at lighter fare/quasi-comedy.  Popcorn anyone?
summary: Joseph Mazzello in his real comedic-drama role ROCKS

reviewText: "Star Kid" seems like it could be a bit of a passion project for writer-director Manny Coto, as it combines a bunch of genres he's worked on: science-fiction, action, and horror. It's also a pretty ambitious feature for a small studio like Trimark Pictures, but not necessarily more so than other films they've produced. Cumulatively, I think it's a unique idea for a movie that could have been pulled off a lot better with a bigger budget and with a broader target audience. I wish more movies like this were being made nowadays, but it's easy to guess why they aren't.The story: Spencer Griffith (Joseph Mazzello) is a troubled kid who comes upon the Cyborsuit (Alex Daniels, stunt double forGeorge Clooney) - a technologically-advanced suit of armor, jettisoned from a distant planet, requiring a host to operate it. Though thrilled with the abilities his new friend enables for him, Spencer doesn't yet realize that his symbiosis will require him to engage the Broodwarrior (Brian Simpson,On Deadly Ground) - a deadly alien soldier who's waged war on the Cyborsuit's home and has followed him to earth.At best, "Star Kid" is a mixture ofE.T.andPower Rangers: there's plenty of entertaining interaction between Spencer and the suit and a good deal of intergalactic cultural misunderstandings, but there are also a lot of stunt and action scenes present (more on those soon). Much like inJurassic Park, Joseph Mazzello can come off as very annoying at times with his high-pitched voice, but in the end he gives a pretty good, layered performance - more so than his older co-stars, even, with the possible exception of Corinne Bohrer (Vice Versa) as a benevolent science teacher. A minor supporting character played by Yumi Adachi inches towards some racial stereotypes, but it's not offensive enough to wreck the movie.I appreciate that the film relies primarily on prosthetics and puppetry to get its special effects across, especially because its CGI effects are very weak by today's standards. The creature designs are pretty entertaining, and unlike some other films I've seen (e.g.Arena), the costumes actually look good in action scenes. However, to my chagrin, there are plenty of action scenes in general but fair few actual fights between the suit and the alien warrior. For the most part, Spencer gets up to shenanigans that are amplified by the suit - sometimes to absurd levels (e.g. the refrigerator scene) - but for a creation designed for combat, he gets up to very little actual fighting.Amazingly, for a film that takes place in generally only one location and over the course of only a single day, this one doesn't feel as though it's missing scope, which is to the director's credit. Nevertheless, the movie's not great: it's as humorous as it ought to be, but lacks the adrenaline rushes that a picture with its premise ought to provide. I wouldn't mind seeing a more bombastic sequel to this one, but I think that's no more than a dream by now.
summary: "What do you call a cow with no legs?"

reviewText: I am a big Joseph Mazzello fan and all his films I've seen have all gotten big 4 or 5's from me in the rating scale so I figured I'd give this one a shot. I was happy I did. The acting is avergley good except for Joseph who did a excellent job as always. The film is about a 12 year old kid Spencer Griffith(Joseph Mazzello) who is lonesome and just wants to be liked, one day when hes inside his room at night reading his comics ext. He catches a glimpse of a bright object falling from the sky and into a old junkyard not too far away. He investigates and ends up finding a cybor suit that he eventually gets inside of thus becoming the 'Star Kid'. He decides to do some payback to bullys and other people who have been mean to him but then a evil monster comes  to the town bent on destroying earth and anything that gets in its way. Thats when the trouble begins.The film is a nice and adventorous tale which i'm sad to say is impossible to find on DVD! I love this movie and is a great film to see if your ever depressed or just want to get 'out of this world'. I recommend it.

reviewText: Friendly-aliens put a talking, interactive, robotic, combat, suit into a little space-ship, and send it into space; to keep it out of the hands of other hostile-aliens. The hostile-aliens send a scout to earth searching for the suit. A boy finds the suit and uses it to get revenge on the school-bully.A lot of thought and expense went into the film's many special-effects. The 1998-effects are not computer-graphics, but believable.Imaginative story, with some humor. Moves at a good pace.Good similar film are: "The Last Star Fighter" (1984), "The Explorers (1985), and even better: "Zathura" (2005).
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a great movie about a kid named Spencer Griffith. He is a pretty normal 12-year-old who gets bullied around a lot. He's into comic books. He wants to be friends with a certain girl in his class but whenever he tries to talk to her he goes mute.One day while he was sitting in his room alone he sees something fall from the sky and land in the local junkyard. He goes to investigate and finds an a capsule. He throws a rock at it. Nothing happens, so he touches it. It opens up to reveal an alien suit that asks him if he needs transport. He says yes and goes inside. Spencer then proceeds to go around town having fun in his suit and getting back at his bullies. But a bigger evil is lurking around and soon he needs to decide the fate of mankind.This is an excellent movie, it is a bit cheesy at times but I like it. Joseph Mazzello is superb as Spencer. This is also the first movie where he was the biggest name. I give this great movie 5 stars. But I don't recommend it to anyone who is not a child at heart or you'll just shrug it off as a bad cheesy movie.PS: Is it just me, or does every Joseph Mazzello movie have things thrown? Especially rocks. Jurassic Park, Radio Flyer, Simon Birch, Three Wishes, and The Cure all have things thrown. It's a Joseph Mazzello movie trademark.
